description: {"blocks":[{"key":"4atvf","text":"This protocol is for agarose gel electrophoresis. To see the full abstract and additional resources, visit the Addgene protocol page.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":111,"length":21}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"B42415D02C2411EA9A3C3B66E57AFC99","url":"https://www.addgene.org/protocols/gel-electrophoresis/"}}}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"adpq8","text":"Analyzing your gel","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bqhas","text":"Using the DNA ladder in the first lane as a guide (the manufacturer's instruction will tell you the size of each band), you can infer the size of the DNA in your sample lanes. For more details on doing diagnostic digests and how to interpret them please see the Diagnostic Digest page.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":262,"length":17}],"data":[]},{"key":"3jbng","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b1osq","text":"Purifying DNA from your gel","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":27}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9gnqs","text":"If you are conducting certain procedures, such as molecular cloning, you will need to purify the DNA away from the agarose gel. For instructions on how to do this, visit the Gel Purification page.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":174,"length":16}],"data":[]},{"key":"2onm9","text":"","type":"header-two","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"642mf","text":"Tips and FAQ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aq0qe","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3opke","text":"How do you get better resolution of bands?","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":42}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aeu4d","text":"A few simple ways to increase the resolution (crispness) of your DNA bands include: a) running the gel at a lower voltage for a longer period of time; b) using a wider/thinner gel comb; or c) loading less DNA into the well. Another method for visualizing very short DNA fragments is polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (PAGE), which is typically used to separate 5 - 500 bp fragments.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"atdpb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"500fl","text":"How do you get better separation of bands?","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":42}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bgj5","text":"If you have similarly sized bands that are running too close together, you can adjust the agarose percentage of the gel to get better separation. A higher percentage agarose gel will help resolve smaller bands from each other, and a lower percentage gel will help separate larger bands.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2gb4g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"54m4e","text":"10% Rule:","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f2t6f","text":"For each sample you want to load on a gel, make 10% more volume than needed because several microliters can be lost in pipetting. For example, if you want to load 1.0 μg in 10 μL, make 1.1 μg in 11 μL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"BCA064A78C444B1A8CD70115E5F6E445","url":"https://www.addgene.org/protocols/diagnostic-digest"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"B2075F4553044AEEB0C16E5CBB90BA09","url":"https://www.addgene.org/plasmid-protocols/gel-purification"}}}}
public_fork_note: This revision takes advantage of using a 0.25x running buffer and higher voltages to significantly decrease the running time of the gel with little or no effect on gel performance.

status.info: We use this protocol and it’s working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"4am8","text":"Measure   of agarose.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":8,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"v9bn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"34ab6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":".6","guid":"85220F00CE5311E9ACBE5992494E117B","id":"49978","label":"","unit":6}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"mrqa","text":"*Pro-Tip*","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":253},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":269}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3qur2","text":"Agarose gels are commonly used in concentrations of 0.7%-2% depending on the size of bands needed to be separated -see FAQ section of this protocol. Simply adjust the mass of agarose in a given volume to make gels of other agarose concentrations (e.g.,   of agarose in   of TAE will make a 2% gel).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"85s3u","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"45r1a","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"amount":"2","guid":"400138C087D011E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":0,"label":"","protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","step_guid":"7AC2F8F087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"1","unit":6},"mutability":"","type":"amount"},"1":{"data":{"amount":"100","guid":"42F12CC087D011E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":0,"label":"","protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","step_guid":"7AC2F8F087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"1","unit":2},"mutability":"","type":"amount"}}}}}}

can be used instead of TAE, labs usually use one or the other, but there is very little difference between the two.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"4":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cro0f","text":"Note, make sure to {"blocks":[{"key":"3adie","text":"Microwave for   to   until the agarose is completely dissolved (but do not overboil the solution, as some of the buffer will evaporate and thus alter the final percentage of agarose in the gel. Many people prefer to microwave in pulses, swirling the flask occasionally as the solution heats up.)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":14,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":19,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"d8ilk","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"8mvd7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cu00o","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"f1qj5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":60,"guid":"D4B04FF087D111E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":"53091","label":"","pause":null,"protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","start":null,"step_guid":"7ACC6ED087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"3"}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":180,"guid":"DD4AEB2087D111E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":"53092","label":"","pause":null,"protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","start":null,"step_guid":"7ACC6ED087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"3"}},"2":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"be3al","text":"CAUTION: HOT! Be careful stirring, eruptive boiling can occur.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"3":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"5ms0b","text":"*Pro-Tip*","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":35},{"key":1,"length":1,"offset":37}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"62tm9","text":"It is a good idea to microwave for  - , stop and swirl, and then continue towards a boil. Keep an eye on it the solution has a tendancy to boil over. Placing saran wrap over the top of the flask can help with this, but is not necessary if you pay close attention.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bgqab","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7b74p","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"duration":30,"guid":"964989C0CE5311E9ACBE5992494E117B","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"start":null},"mutability":"","type":"duration"},"1":{"data":{"duration":45,"guid":"9BAACBE0CE5311E9ACBE5992494E117B","id":0,"label":"","pause":null,"start":null},"mutability":"","type":"duration"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"h7m1","text":"Let agarose solution cool down to about   (about when you can comfortably keep your hand on the flask), about  .","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":40,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":110,"length":1}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"temperature","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"7DBED83087CF11E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":"28554","label":"","protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","step_guid":"7ACC95E087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"4","temperature":"50","unit":10}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":300,"guid":"AD08E76087D011E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":"53093","label":"","pause":null,"protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","start":null,"step_guid":"7ACC95E087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"4"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"d7cnk","text":"Add Midori Green (25,000x) to a final concentration of 1x (about   -  of lab stock solution per   gel). EtBr binds to the DNA and allows you to visualize the DNA under ultraviolet (UV) light.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":65,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":68,"length":1},{"key":2,"offset":96,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"arj2i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"34oit","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4b9ai","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"98qfs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"d67o6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"2","guid":"1C3F677087D211E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":"49980","label":"","protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","step_guid":"7ACCBCF087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"5","unit":1}},"1":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"3","guid":"B5FEB76087CF11E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":"49981","label":"","protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","step_guid":"7ACCBCF087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"5","unit":1}},"2":{"type":"amount","mutability":"","data":{"amount":"60","guid":"A117276087CF11E98858AD0DD3942FFE","id":"49982","label":"","protocol_name":"Agarose Gel Electrophoresis","step_guid":"7ACCBCF087B111E9BC49CFC6897C89BE","step_number":"5","unit":2}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"eflfh","text":"Pour the agarose into a gel tray with the well comb in place.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6mv4f","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"4hjl7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"fh1gm","text":"*Pro-Tip*","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6nne9","text":"Pour slowly to avoid bubbles which will disrupt the gel. Any bubbles can be pushed away from the well comb or towards the sides/edges of the gel with a pipette tip.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Loading Samples and Running an Agarose Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"49ud6","text":"Add loading buffer (e.g., to6x Purple Loading Dye from NEB) to each of your DNA samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cq5a8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"47fr4","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"5tknh","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"64vgh","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a855d","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"2C51971087D111E98858AD0DD3942FFE","height":197,"id":"41736","is_image":true,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9lc5l","text":"loading a gel","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"Screen Shot 2019-06-05 at 4.32.53 PM.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/pr-journal/bi2i7esn.png","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/pr-journal/bi2i7esn.png","width":351}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dl312","text":"Note: Loading buffer serves two purposes: 1) it provides a visible dye that helps with gel loading and allows you to gauge how far the DNA has migrated; 2) it contains a high percentage of glycerol that increases the density of your DNA sample causing it to settle to the bottom of the gel well, instead of diffusing in the buffer.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4tohn","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5cg7l","text":"Note: Some samples will already contain loading buffers and running dyes (e.g., some PCR master mixes, some DNA ladders), so you do not need to add loading dye to these samples.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Loading Samples and Running an Agarose Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"c4ttu","text":"Once solidified, place the agarose gel into the gel box (electrophoresis unit).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Loading Samples and Running an Agarose Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2ktvr","text":"Fill the gel box with 0.25xTAE (or TBE) until the gel is covered.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d8a77","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"713de","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Loading Samples and Running an Agarose Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"f05n3","text":"Carefully load a molecular weight ladder into one lane of the gel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2uke6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"502jj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d9mv4","text":"Note, when loading the sample in the well, maintain positive pressure on the sample to prevent bubbles or buffer from entering the tip. Place the very top of the tip of the pipette into the buffer just above the well. Very slowly and steadily, push the sample out and watch as the sample fills the well. After all of the sample is unloaded, push the pipettor to the second stop and carefully raise the pipette straight out of the buffer.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Loading Samples and Running an Agarose Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"57upp","text":"Carefully load your samples into the additional wells of the gel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"afqk6","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"f2eb9","text":"    ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"45rug","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"6DBDF13087D111E98858AD0DD3942FFE","height":223,"id":"41738","is_image":true,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9ab48","text":"gel loaded with samples","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"Screen Shot 2019-06-05 at 4.35.04 PM.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/pr-journal/bi2k7esn.png","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/pr-journal/bi2k7esn.png","width":399}}}}

steps.section: Loading Samples and Running an Agarose Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"ej8d3","text":"Run the gel at 250-300 V until the dye line is approximately 75-80% of the way down the gel. A typical run time is about  - , depending on the gel concentration and voltage.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":121,"length":1},{"key":1,"offset":123,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"e4800","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"dat2l","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":900,"guid":"F203BF10CE5311E9ACBE5992494E117B","id":"53098","label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"1":{"type":"duration","mutability":"","data":{"duration":1500,"guid":"F64E8820CE5311E9ACBE5992494E117B","id":"53099","label":"","pause":null,"preset":[],"start":null}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4e64d","text":"Note: Black is negative, red is positive. The DNA is negatively charged and will run towards the positive electrode. Always Run to Red.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

steps.section: Loading Samples and Running an Agarose Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"6eacu","text":"Turn OFF power, disconnect the electrodes from the power source, and then carefully remove the gel from the gel box.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: Loading Samples and Running an Agarose Gel
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7pkg1","text":"Using any device that has UV light, visualize your DNA fragments. The fragments of DNA are usually referred to as ‘bands’ due to their appearance on the gel.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cien7","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"1jfms","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7mo6g","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"aecou","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"cr26p","text":"CAUTION: When using UV light, protect your skin by wearing safety goggles or a face shield, gloves and a lab coat.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":9,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"a609m","text":"*Pro-Tip*","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3l65a","text":"If you will be purifying the DNA for later use, use long-wavelength UV and expose for as little time as possible to minimize damage to the DNA.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

title: Fast Agarose Gel Electrophoresis-Chem 384/584
